abstract.p: Hemotropic mycoplasmas, particularly Mycoplasma wenyonii and “Candidatus Mycoplasma haematobovis”, are increasingly recognized as emerging vector-borne pathogens of veterinary importance in cattle and buffalo. Due to their complex epidemiology and the limited understanding of their pathogenic mechanisms, hemoplasma infections in large ruminants are often underdiagnosed and underreported, especially in resource-limited settings. This study investigated the genetic diversity and phylogenetic relationships of hemotropic Mycoplasma species in blood samples collected from cattle and buffalo across seven provinces in Thailand between 2016 and 2023. A total of 422 samples (214 from cattle and 208 from buffalo) were analyzed, with 373 testing positive for hemotropic Mycoplasma DNA. Phylogenetic analyses of the 16S and 23S rRNA gene sequences revealed two distinct clades corresponding to M. wenyonii and “Ca. M. haematobovis”. Most sequences clustered with M. wenyonii strains from multiple countries, while a smaller subset grouped with “Ca. M. haematobovis” strains. Intraspecific sequence similarity among M. wenyonii 16S rRNA gene sequences ranged from 97.29% to 100%, whereas “Ca. M. haematobovis” sequences showed similarities ranging from 99.75% to 100%. Interspecific similarity between the two species ranged from 83.48% to 84.34%. For the 23S rRNA gene sequences, M. wenyonii exhibited intraspecific similarity levels ranging from 90.94% to 100%, while “Ca. M. haematobovis” sequences demonstrated 99.53% similarity; interspecific similarity for this gene ranged from 76.69% to 77.34%. We identified 11 nucleotide sequence types (ntSTs) for M. wenyonii, with ntST10 being the most widely distributed, shared among isolates from Cuba, Thailand, Japan, and Brazil. The single “Ca. M. haematobovis” sequence type detected in this study clustered within ntST7, alongside sequences from Cuba, Malaysia, Brazil, Turkey, Kyrgyzstan, and Japan. These findings highlight the substantial genetic diversity and broad geographical distribution of hemotropic Mycoplasma species in Thailand and emphasize the critical importance of molecular screening for managing the risk of pathogen transmission within livestock populations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hemotropic Mycoplasma species (hemoplasmas) are epierythrocytic, cell wall-less bacteria that adhere to the surface of red blood cells and are known to cause hemolytic anemia in a wide range of mammalian hosts (Ghauri et al., 2024; Narapakdeesakul et al., 2024). In cattle and buffalo, hemoplasmas, particularly Mycoplasma wenyonii and “Candidatus Mycoplasma haematobovis”, are increasingly recognized as emerging pathogens of veterinary significance. Although infections are often subclinical or mild, they can give rise to severe clinical symptoms under conditions of physiological stress, immunosuppression, or co-infection. Common clinical manifestations include anemia, fever, peripheral edema, reproductive disorders, and decreased milk production, all of which compromise animal health, welfare, and productivity (Congli et al., 2011; Genova et al., 2011; Tatsukawa et al., 2021; Kamani et al., 2023).

Hemoplasmas are primarily transmitted by hematophagous arthropods, such as ticks and biting flies, although iatrogenic transmission also occurs. Due to their complex epidemiology and the limited understanding of their pathogenic mechanisms, hemoplasma infections in large ruminants are frequently underdiagnosed and underreported, particularly in resource-limited settings (Tagawa et al., 2012). The advent of molecular diagnostics, especially polymerase chain reaction (PCR)-based techniques, has significantly improved the detection and characterization of these organisms, revealing a broader host range and a wider geographical distribution than previously recognized. Understanding the prevalence, molecular diversity, and clinical implications of hemoplasmas in large ruminants is essential for the development of effective diagnostic tools, preventive strategies, and management protocols. This need is particularly urgent in regions where livestock play a vital role in food security and rural livelihoods. As awareness of these pathogens grows, there is an increasing need for integrated surveillance and control programmes to mitigate their impact.

Genetic characterization of hemoplasmas through sequencing and phylogenetic analysis has become crucial for understanding pathogen diversity, host interactions, and potential virulence. Studies utilizing PCR and sequencing technologies have revealed considerable genetic diversity in M. wenyonii among cattle populations in China (Congli et al., 2011), suggesting the presence of multiple lineages with varying pathogenicity and transmission dynamics. Similar observations have been reported in Europe. In Germany, Messick (2004) identified distinct variants of M. wenyonii and “Ca. M. haematobovis”, indicating multiple introductions and local adaptation. In Switzerland, Meli et al. (2010) employed phylogenetic approaches to detect genetically distinct clusters, highlighting the influence of environmental factors and livestock management practices on pathogen evolution. In Asia, research from Japan uncovered unique genetic lineages of hemoplasmas associated with specific clinical outcomes (Tagawa et al., 2012). In Thailand, Thongmeesee et al. (2022a) documented the genetic diversity of M. wenyonii and “Ca. M. haematobovis” and provided molecular evidence of M. wenyonii in flies collected from buffalo farms, emphasizing the roles of arthropod vectors and animal movement in disease transmission.

Despite these advances, significant knowledge gaps persist regarding the genetic diversity, pathogenic mechanisms, and evolutionary dynamics of hemotropic Mycoplasma species in large ruminants, particularly in Southeast Asian countries such as Thailand. The objectives of this study are to assess the prevalence and geographical distribution of M. wenyonii and “Ca. M. haematobovis” in cattle and buffalo across seven provinces in Thailand from 2016 to 2023, and to investigate their genetic diversity and phylogenetic relationships using molecular markers derived from the 16S and 23S rRNA genes.

sec.title: Sample collection
sec.p: This study was conducted as part of a broader investigation into vector-borne pathogens, as previously described by Templeton et al. (2016), Nguyen et al. (2020a, b), and Arnuphapprasert et al. (2023). Blood samples were collected from cattle (Bos taurus) and Asian water buffalo (Bubalus bubalis) across seven provinces in Thailand: Nan, Uthai Thani, Mukdahan, Lampang, Nakhon Sawan, Nakhon Ratchasima, and Chachoengsao (Supplementary file 1: Fig. S1). Samples from both cattle and buffalo were collected from smallholder farms, each housing fewer than 10 animals, during routine vaccination activities. At most farms, no measures for the prevention of blood-sucking insects were in place at the time of sampling. Blood was aseptically drawn from the jugular vein using sterile syringes and transferred into acid-citrate-dextrose tubes to prevent coagulation. For each animal, associated data, including identification number, age, sex, body condition score, and the presence of ectoparasites, were systematically recorded. Samples were transported in ice-cooled containers to the Faculty of Veterinary Science, Chulalongkorn University, where they were stored at −20 °C until further processing.

sec.title: DNA extraction
sec.p: DNA from buffalo blood samples collected in 2023 was extracted using the NucleoSpin® Blood Kit (Macherey-Nagel, Düren, Germany), following the manufacturer’s instructions. Briefly, 200 μl of whole blood was lysed, and DNA was purified using silica membrane columns and elution in 50 μl of elution buffer. The concentration and purity of the extracted DNA were assessed using a NanoDrop™ 1000 Spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, USA) by measuring absorbance at 260 and 280 nm. DNA samples from previous studies were used directly for the detection of hemotropic Mycoplasma DNA (Templeton et al., 2016; Nguyen et al., 2020a, 2020b; Arnuphapprasert et al., 2023).

sec.title: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and DNA cloning
sec.p: A polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay was conducted to detect hemotropic Mycoplasma DNA by targeting conserved regions of the 16S and 23S ribosomal RNA (rRNA) genes. Primer sets specific to hemotropic Mycoplasma were adopted from previous studies: for the 16S rRNA gene, Hm16SF1 (5′-GAA CAG CCG CAA TGG GAT TGA G-3′) and Hm16SR1 (5′-GAC CTG GGA ACG TAT TCA CCC TG-3′) (Thongmeesee et al., 2022b) (Supplementary file 1: Fig. S2); and for the 23S rRNA gene, Hm23SF1 (5′-GGC TAG SGG TGA AAT TCC AAT CG-3′) and Hm23SR1 (5′-GTA AAG CTT CAY AGG GTC TTT CCG TC-3′) (Narapakdeesakul et al., 2024).

PCR was performed in a 12.5 μl reaction containing 1× KOD Fx Neo buffer, 2.5 mM MgCl2, 0.4 mM dNTPs, 0.2 μM of each primer, 0.25 U of KOD Fx Neo DNA polymerase (Toyobo, Osaka, Japan), and 1 μl of DNA template (c.10 ng), with the final volume adjusted using sterile distilled water. Thermocycling conditions followed those described by Thongmeesee et al. (2022b) and Narapakdeesakul et al. (2024). To minimise the risk of non-specific amplification and contamination, rigorous quality control measures were applied during assay setup. Separate laboratory areas were designated for pre- and post-PCR procedures, and the use of filter tips together with dedicated pipettes, was strictly maintained. Each PCR run incorporated negative controls (sterile distilled water) and positive controls (DNA previously confirmed as Mycoplasma haemominutum from a cat).

PCR products were visualized by electrophoresis on 1.5% agarose gels stained with RedSafe™ (Intron Biotechnology, Gyeonggi-do, South Korea) and observed under UV light. A 100-bp DNA ladder was used to estimate product sizes. Positive samples showed bands of approximately 1030 bp for the 16S rRNA gene and 1200 bp for the 23S rRNA gene (Supplementary file 1: Fig. S3).

Direct sequencing of non-cloned PCR products generated poor-quality chromatograms with overlapping peaks, rendering the results unreliable. To overcome these limitations, cloning was performed. PCR reactions were scaled up in a 50 μl reaction, purified using the NucleoSpin® Gel and PCR Clean-up Kit (Macherey-Nagel, Düren, Germany), and cloned using the pGEM®-T vector system (Promega, Madison, USA) with minor protocol modifications. Ligated DNA (10–25 ng/μl) was incubated overnight at 4 °C, then transformed into E. coli DH5α competent cells via heat-shock. Transformed cells were plated on ampicillin-supplemented LB agar, incubated overnight at 37 °C, and positive colonies were selected for plasmid purification and sequencing. Sequencing was performed in both directions using the primers described above (Thongmeesee et al., 2022b; Narapakdeesakul et al., 2024). Forward and reverse reads were aligned, visualized, and assembled with BioEdit v7.2.5 (Hall, 1999) to generate a consensus sequence for analysis. Primer-derived nucleotides were removed, and the overlapping regions between forward and reverse reads provided sufficient coverage to ensure accurate sequence determination. In cases where the initial PCR products were inadequate for sequencing, new PCR reactions were prepared under stringent contamination controls. Preliminary sequencing revealed greater than 99% identity among clones, enabling the selection of a single representative clone per sample for subsequent analyses. Of the 373 haemoplasma-positive samples identified by PCR, 26 amplicons from the 16S rRNA gene and 23 from the 23S rRNA gene were successfully sequenced using the Sanger method.

sec.title: Phylogenetic analysis
sec.p: Sequences were aligned with the ClustalW algorithm incorporated in BioEdit v7.2.5 (Hall, 1999). Genetic diversity indices, including the number of haplotypes (H), haplotype diversity (Hd), nucleotide diversity (π), and the average number of nucleotide differences (κ), were calculated using DnaSP v6.12.03 (Rozas et al., 2017). Sequences were compared to reference data in GenBank using BLASTn to confirm species-level similarity. Phylogenetic trees were constructed using the Maximum Likelihood (ML) method with the TN+F+G4 substitution model in IQ-TREE. Node support was evaluated with 1000 bootstrap replicates. Bayesian inference (BI) analysis was conducted via the CIPRES Science Gateway, employing 100,000,000 Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) generations, sampling every 1000 generations, and applying a 25% “burn-in”. Resulting phylogenies were visualized using FigTree v1.4.4 (http://tree.bio.ed.ac.uk/software/figtree). Nodes with bootstrap values ≥ 70% were considered robustly supported.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: The prevalence of hemotropic Mycoplasma infection was calculated as the proportion of PCR-positive samples relative to the total number of animals tested. Differences in infection rates between cattle and buffalo were evaluated using the Chi-square test, including associations between infection status and host factors. Statistical analyses were conducted using SPSS Statistics software (version 22; IBM Corp.). Additionally, co-infections involving vector-borne pathogens in cattle and buffalo were contextualized with reference to previous studies (Nguyen et al., 2020a, 2020b; Arnuphapprasert et al., 2023). Specifically, pathogens identified in the present study including hemotropic Mycoplasma were summarised descriptively (Supplementary file 2: Tables S1 and S2).

sec.title: Molecular investigation of hemotropic Mycoplasma in cattle and buffalo in Thailand
sec.p:
A total of 422 animals, comprising 214 cattle and 208 Asian water buffalo, were sampled across seven provinces in Thailand (Nan, Uthai Thani, Mukdahan, Lampang, Nakhon Sawan, Nakhon Ratchasima, and Chachoengsao) between 2016 and 2023. Sample distribution varied by province, with the largest numbers collected from Nakhon Ratchasima (n = 71 in 2018 and n = 83 in 2019), followed by Chachoengsao (n = 94) and Mukdahan (n = 59) (Table 1). PCR assays targeting the 16S rRNA gene of hemotropic Mycoplasma spp. detected the pathogens in 373 of the 422 samples, resulting in an overall prevalence of 88.39 % (95% CI: 84.98–91.10%). The highest detection rate was recorded in Uthai Thani in 2017, where all tested cattle were PCR-positive (6/6; 100%, 95% CI: 60.97–100.00%). Similarly high prevalence rates were observed in Nan Province in 2016, with 97.67% of cattle testing positive (42/43; 95% CI: 87.94–99.59%), and in Mukdahan, where 96.61% of buffalo were positive in 2016 (57/59; 95% CI: 88.46–99.07%). In Lampang, 94.34% of buffalo were positive in 2016 (50/53; 95% CI: 84.63–98.06%), while in Chachoengsao, 93.62 % of buffalo tested positive in 2023 (88/94; 95% CI: 86.77–97.04%). In Nakhon Ratchasima, the prevalence among cattle varied, with 73.24% testing positive in 2018 (52/71; 95% CI: 61.95–82.15%) and 80.72% in 2019 (67/83; 95% CI: 70.96–87.77%). In contrast, a comparatively lower detection rate was recorded in Nakhon Sawan, where 84.62% of cattle tested positive in 2018 (11/13; 95% CI: 57.77–95.67%). Overall, hemotropic Mycoplasma spp. were detected in 82.41% of cattle (178/216; 95% CI: 76.78–86.91%) and 92.72% of buffalo (195/206; 95% CI: 90.69–96.99%). Chi-square analysis revealed a statistically significant association between infection status and geographical location (χ2 = 31.34, P < 0.001), as well as between infection status and host species (χ2 = 15.24, P < 0.001).Table 1

Co-infections were frequently observed among vector-borne pathogens. Double infections were most common between hemotropic Mycoplasma spp. and piroplasms (37.96%), followed by hemotropic Mycoplasma spp. with Anaplasma spp. (33.53%), and Anaplasma spp. with piroplasms (14.81%). Triple infections involving hemotropic Mycoplasma spp., Anaplasma spp., and piroplasms were also detected (16.20%) (Supplementary file 2: Tables S1 and S2).

sec.title: Genetic diversity
sec.p: In this study, 32 sequences of the 16S rRNA gene were generated (29 for M. wenyonii and 3 for “Ca. M. haematobovis”). For the 23S rRNA gene, 24 sequences were generated (22 for M. wenyonii and 2 for “Ca. M. haematobovis”). These were the only two hemoplasma species identified. Sequence inclusion was determined based on the quality of chromatograms generated through Sanger sequencing. BLASTN analysis of the 16S rRNA gene sequences (814–839 bp) revealed percent identities exceeding 98% (Supplementary file 2: Table S3), while the 23S rRNA gene sequences (644–662 bp) showed percent identities greater than 93% for M. wenyonii and 91% for “Ca. M. haematobovis” (Supplementary file 2: Table S4).

The genetic diversity of Mycoplasma wenyonii and “Candidatus Mycoplasma haematobovis” was assessed through sequence analysis of the 16S rRNA and 23S rRNA genes. Following the removal of low-quality regions and primer sequences, 29 high-quality M. wenyonii 16S rRNA gene sequences and 3 “Ca. M. haematobovis” sequences, each 841 base pairs (bp) in length, were obtained (Table 2). A total of 24 nucleotide substitutions were identified, resulting in a haplotype diversity (Hd) of 0.985 ± 0.014. Nucleotide diversity (π) was estimated at 0.013 ± 0.005, with an average number of nucleotide differences (κ) of 10.938.Table 2

In comparison, the two “Ca. M. haematobovis” sequences (667 bp) exhibited a haplotype diversity of 1.000 ± 0.500, a nucleotide diversity of 0.005 ± 0.004, and a κ-value of 3.000.

sec.title: Intraspecific and interspecific sequence similarity of 16S and 23S rRNA genes
sec.p:
The intraspecific sequence similarity of the 16S rRNA gene among Mycoplasma wenyonii sequences (n = 29) ranged from 97.29% to 100%, whereas the three “Ca. M. haematobovis” sequences exhibited a similarity range of 99.75–100% (Fig. 1A). Interspecific comparisons between M. wenyonii and “Ca. M. haematobovis” revealed sequence similarities ranging from 83.48% to 84.34% (Fig. 1A). Based on 23S rRNA gene sequences, the intraspecific similarity among M. wenyonii sequences (n = 22) varied from 90.94% to 100%, while the two “Ca. M. haematobovis” sequences showed a similarity of 99.53% (Fig. 1B). Interspecific comparisons of the 23S rRNA gene sequences showed a similarity range of 76.69–77.34% (Fig. 1B).Fig. 1
Comparison of nucleotide sequence similarities among Mycoplasma wenyonii and “Candidatus Mycoplasma haematobovis” based on 16S rRNA (A) and 23S rRNA (B) gene sequences. The scale bar indicates the expected number of substitutions per site.Fig. 1

sec.title: Phylogenetic analysis
sec.p:
Phylogenetic analysis was conducted using the 16S rRNA gene sequences obtained in this study (n = 26), revealing two distinct clades (Fig. 2). The majority of sequences clustered with M. wenyonii strains previously reported from a range of countries, including the UK, Cuba, Kyrgyzstan, China, Brazil, Japan, Sweden, Mexico, Mozambique, the USA, and Thailand. Two sequences were grouped with “Ca. M. haematobovis” strains from Malaysia, Cuba, Brazil, Kyrgyzstan, Turkey, Japan, Switzerland, and Thailand (Fig. 2). Similarly, phylogenetic analysis of 23S rRNA gene sequences (n = 23) identified two distinct species (Fig. 3). Twenty-one sequences clustered within the Mycoplasma suis group, closely aligning with M. wenyonii sequences from the USA and with uncultured Mycoplasma species previously detected in Thailand. The remaining two sequences formed a distinct cluster within the Mycoplasma haemofelis clade, clearly separated from other species within this group (Fig. 3).Fig. 2

sec.title: Nucleotide sequence types (ntSTs) network of 16S rRNA and 23S rRNA genes of M. wenyonii and “Ca. M. haematobovis”
sec.p:
Only representative sequences from each unique type were included in the phylogenetic analysis to minimise redundancy and enhance clarity. Accordingly, 26 Mycoplasma 16S rRNA gene sequences generated in this study, together with 35 sequences obtained from external sources, were analyzed. Based on the 16S rRNA gene sequences of Mycoplasma wenyonii and “Ca. M. haematobovis” obtained in this study, as well as sequences previously deposited in the GenBank database, 11 distinct nucleotide sequence types (ntSTs) were identified for M. wenyonii. These included ntST1, ntST 2, ntST5, ntST6, ntST9, ntST10, ntST15, ntST16, ntST17, ntST18, and ntST19 (Fig. 4). Among these, ntST10 was the most prevalent, comprising sequences from Cuba, Thailand, Japan, Brazil, and the present study. For “Ca. M. haematobovis”, the sequences obtained in this study were classified as ntST7, clustering with sequences previously reported from Cuba, Malaysia, Brazil, Turkey, Kyrgyzstan, and Japan. These findings highlight the genetic diversity of hemotropic Mycoplasma species and suggest the presence of shared sequence types across geographically distant regions (Fig. 4). Due to the limited availability of 23S rRNA gene sequences for M. wenyonii and “Ca. M. haematobovis”, nucleotide sequence type (ntST) network analysis could not be performed and was therefore not included in this study.Fig. 4
Nucleotide sequence type (ntST) network based on partial nucleotide alignments of 16S rRNA gene (379 bp) for Mycoplasma wenyonii (pink zone) and “Ca. M. haematobovis” (blue zone). The network was constructed using the median joining network algorithm.Fig. 4

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study investigated the prevalence and genetic diversity of hemotropic Mycoplasma infections in cattle and Asian water buffalo across seven provinces in Thailand from 2016 to 2023. The overall detection rate was notably high at 88.39%, highlighting the widespread presence of these pathogens among ruminant livestock. Such a substantial prevalence raises significant concerns regarding animal health and agricultural productivity, as hemotropic Mycoplasma infections are frequently associated with chronic anemia, reduced milk yield, and impaired reproductive performance. These adverse effects are often exacerbated under physiological stress conditions, including elevated ambient temperatures linked to global climate change or concurrent infections with other pathogens (Genova et al., 2011; Ferreira and Ruegg, 2024).

Prevalence varied considerably among provinces, with the highest rates recorded in Uthai Thani (100%), Nan (97.67%), Mukdahan (96.61%), and Chachoengsao (93.62%). These findings align with previous research indicating that tropical and subtropical climates, characterized by high humidity, elevated temperatures, and abundant populations of hematophagous arthropods, create favorable environments for Mycoplasma spp. transmission (Boularias et al., 2020). Blood-feeding arthropods such as ticks and flies are likely the primary vectors facilitating pathogen spread in these regions (Arendt et al., 2024). Supporting this notion, Thongmeesee et al. (2022a) identified hemotropic Mycoplasma DNA in blood-feeding flies collected at a buffalo farm in Chachoengsao. Conversely, lower prevalences were observed in Nakhon Ratchasima (73.24% in 2018; 80.72% in 2019) and Nakhon Sawan (84.62%). However, small sample size from Nakhon Sawan was acknowledged. These provinces typically employ more intensive livestock management practices, which likely benefit from improved veterinary care and effective vector control strategies, including the routine applications of acaricides and insecticides (Martviset et al., 2024).

Notably, buffalo exhibited a higher overall infection rate than cattle, diverging from previous studies that reported no significant interspecies differences (Díaz-Sánchez et al., 2019; Erol et al., 2023). The notably higher prevalence of hemotropic Mycoplasma infection in buffalo compared to cattle observed in this study may be attributed to differences in their husbandry practices, environmental exposure, and possibly host susceptibility (Tagawa et al., 2012). During our field surveys, buffalo were predominantly raised in extensive systems, with free-ranging access to wetlands, riversides, and open pastures. Such environments are highly conducive to the proliferation of vectors, particularly hematophagous vectors such as tick or biting flies known to transmit hemoplasmas mechanically (Neimark et al., 2001). Continuous exposure to these habitats likely increases the probability of vector contact and subsequent pathogen transmission. In contrast, cattle were more frequently managed under semi-intensive to intensive farming systems, where animals are housed in shelters or confined to limited grazing areas with restricted vector access (Jones et al., 2018). These systems often implement structured biosecurity protocols, vector control measures (e.g. insecticides, regular cleaning), and routine veterinary oversight, all of which contribute to reducing the risk of infection (Murcia-Mono et al., 2025). Moreover, differences in species-specific immune responses may also play a role in the observed disparity. While current knowledge of comparative immune responses to hemoplasmas in buffalo versus cattle is limited, it is plausible that buffalo may exhibit subclinical or chronic infections that contribute to persistent circulation of the pathogen within herds. Additionally, buffalo may serve as reservoir hosts due to longer periods of bacteremia, thus sustaining transmission cycles in endemic areas (Díaz-Sánchez et al., 2019).

The particularly high infection rates among buffalo in Mukdahan (96.61%) and Chachoengsao (93.62%) underscore the influence of traditional farming practices on disease transmission dynamics. Hemotropic Mycoplasma infections impose substantial clinical and economic burdens, including anemia, lethargy, reduced weight gain, reproductive failure, and persistent subclinical infections (Strugnell and McAuliffe, 2012; Nouvel et al., 2019; Ferreira and Ruegg, 2024). The elevated detection rates reported here suggest that many animals may serve as undiagnosed carriers of subclinical infections, contributing to productivity losses and increased vulnerability to secondary infections. These concerns are particularly pronounced in Uthai Thani and Nan, where prevalence reached 100% and 97.67%, respectively. Without the implementation of effective control measures, these areas may face the risk of sustained economic impacts. The detection of multiple co-infections involving hemotropic Mycoplasma spp., Anaplasma spp., and piroplasms suggests overlapping transmission dynamics, most likely mediated by shared tick species or possibly other hematophagous vectors. Such concurrent infections may complicate clinical manifestations, impede accurate diagnosis, and potentially exacerbate disease severity. Moreover, the occurrence of triple infections highlights the capacity of these pathogens to circulate simultaneously within the same host populations, reinforcing the need for integrated surveillance and control strategies.

The findings strongly support the hypothesis that vector-borne transmission constitutes the primary route for Mycoplasma dissemination. Hematophagous arthropods, particularly ticks and flies, are abundant in the surveyed regions, where environmental and ecological conditions such as high temperature, elevated humidity, and dense vegetation favor vector proliferation (Thongmeesee et al., 2022a; Arendt et al., 2024; Arnuphapprasert et al., 2024). Livestock raised under free-ranging systems, especially in Nan, Mukdahan, and Uthai Thani, are especially vulnerable due to limited biosecurity measures, facilitating the spread of these pathogens. These results underscore the necessity of routine screening for hemotropic Mycoplasma infections in the context of livestock trade to mitigate the risk of transboundary disease transmission.

Genetic analyses revealed high haplotype diversity among Mycoplasma wenyonii sequences, suggesting substantial genetic variability and considerable adaptive potential. In contrast, “Ca. M. haematobovis” showed lower apparent diversity at the 16S rRNA gene, suggesting a relatively conserved population structure; however, this observation should be interpreted with caution, given the limited number of obtained sequences, as not all positive samples were sequenced and only a single clone for each PCR product was sequenced. These results contribute to a better understanding of the evolutionary dynamics, clinical variation, and control of these pathogens. The observed interspecific divergence in both the 16S and 23S rRNA gene sequences reinforces the utility of these genetic markers for species identification and phylogenetic analyses.

Phylogenetic analyses of M. wenyonii and “Ca. M. haematobovis” further elucidated their genetic heterogeneity and evolutionary relationships. Sequences from both the 16S and 23S rRNA genes provided robust frameworks for evaluating intra- and interspecific variation. The 16S rRNA phylogeny consistently segregated M. wenyonii and “Ca. M. haematobovis” into distinct clades. Most M. wenyonii sequences clustered with previously reported strains from geographically diverse regions, including the UK, Brazil, China, and Thailand, reflecting the conserved nature of the gene alongside the species’ broad host range and environmental adaptability. By contrast, “Ca. M. haematobovis” sequences exhibited more geographically restricted clustering, aligning closely with isolates from Malaysia, Brazil, and Turkey. Despite sharing overlapping ecological niches and vector species, the clear phylogenetic separation confirms their classification as distinct taxa.

Analysis of the 23S rRNA gene revealed similar patterns but offered even greater resolution for distinguishing closely related strains. Mycoplasma wenyonii exhibited greater sequence variability at the 23S rRNA locus compared to the 16S rRNA gene, suggesting a higher evolutionary rate. This variability may reflect regional adaptations or strain-specific differentiation. Conversely, “Ca. M. haematobovis” demonstrated minimal sequence variation in the 23S rRNA gene, suggesting a genetically stable population likely shaped by evolutionary constraints or limited selective pressures. The distinct phylogenetic patterns observed based on 23S rRNA gene sequences emphasize the gene’s value in species delimitation and evolutionary investigations.

Interspecies sequence similarity between M. wenyonii and “Ca. M. haematobovis” ranged from 83.48% to 84.34% for the 16S rRNA gene, and from 76.69% to 77.34% for the 23S rRNA gene, further supporting their evolutionary divergence. These findings align with the hypothesis that both species originated from a common ancestor but have since diverged to occupy different ecological niches or host species (Murugesan et al., 2024). The greater genetic diversity observed in M. wenyonii may account for its broader host range and wider geographical distribution. In contrast, the lower diversity found in “Ca. M. haematobovis” suggests a more specialized adaptation. The global clustering of M. wenyonii isolates indicates that vector ecology, climatic conditions, and international livestock movement are likely major drivers for its widespread dissemination. Although “Ca. M. haematobovis” appears more geographically restricted, its detection across several countries suggests a potential to emerge as a globally significant pathogen, particularly in tropical and subtropical regions.

Nonetheless, the limited number of “Ca. M. haematobovis” and M. haemofelis sequences analyzed in this study restricts broader conclusions regarding their global diversity and distribution (Chamberlain et al., 2012). Future research should aim to incorporate larger sample sizes, a broader range of geographical origins, and greater diversity of host species. Whole-genome sequencing would provide deeper insights into evolutionary processes, phylogenetics and pathogenesis. Furthermore, investigating associations between genetic variation and clinical outcomes may facilitate the development of more targeted disease control strategies and veterinary interventions.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study provides a comprehensive molecular analysis of hemotropic Mycoplasma species infecting cattle and Asian water buffalo across seven provinces in Thailand, revealing a high overall prevalence. Detection rates varied significantly by province and host species, with buffalo showing higher infection rates than cattle. Genetic diversity analyses of Mycoplasma wenyonii and “Ca. M. haematobovis” identified distinct nucleotide sequence types (ntSTs) shared across geographically distant regions, suggesting the emergence of globally dominant strains. Phylogenetic analyses based on 16S and 23S rRNA gene sequences confirmed the presence of two distinct clades, corresponding to M. wenyonii and “Ca. M. haematobovis”, among Thai ruminants. Sequence typing further demonstrated the predominance of ntST10 for M. wenyonii, shared with isolates from Cuba, Japan, Brazil, and Thailand, and the presence of ntST7 for “Ca. M. haematobovis”, detected across six countries. These findings highlight the extensive genetic diversity and broad geographical distribution of hemotropic Mycoplasma species in ruminants, offering critical insights into their phylogenetic relationships and evolutionary dynamics.
